subtitle: Thinking Allowed – conversations on the
leading edge of knowledge and discovery with
psychologist Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello and welcome.
I'm Jeffrey Mishlove.
Today we will be exploring the relationship between psyche and matter.
With me is Dr. Todd Hayen, who is the author
of a recently published book called Ancient
Egypt and Modern Psychotherapy – Sacred Science and the Search for Soul.
Dr. Hayen is a depth psychologist with a
psychotherapy practice in Toronto, Ontario, Canada.
Welcome Todd.
Thank you.
Thank you.
In your book you've done something that I
am not aware of in any other book explicitly
about psychotherapy, which is you refer to some of the more exotic literature in macro
psychokinesis.
You're looking at what are the implications of
these empirical findings for our understanding
of the psyche and how it interacts with the material world.
I can't think of anything more appropriate, so
I commend you for looking at this literature.
I'm amazed that other psychotherapists seem to ignore it.
I agree.
I agree.
I do think I was a little brave to go out there and I could have gone into it quite
a bit more, obviously.
The little samples I presented are pretty small
sampling, but I think it was very important
to ease it in to the literature about psychotherapy,
but I think it definitely is relevant, just
like you're saying.
I don't think it's common that people make that connection.
Even people that are fine with the ideas, I don't think they see it as necessarily
relevant to psychotherapy.
Well, it's interesting that the three cases
you cite have all been covered in this Making
Allowed series, two of them have been extensively
reported on by the philosopher Stephen Browdy,
who has been a guest on this program many times.
It deals with my own research, but let's review
that because I'm sure there are many people
viewing right now who haven't seen these other videos.
Let's start with the case of Katie, the gold leaf lady.
Right.
Would you like to explain that one?
Because you're much more familiar with it, probably.
I had met Stephen through his book, The Gold
Leaf Lady, and one of the reasons why I chose
those three, or the reason why I chose those
three, because there's obviously many others,
is because I personally know you and I personally know Stephen.
Former chairman of the philosophy department at
the University of Maryland, Baltimore County,
a very rigorous analytical philosopher.
That of course is what attracted me to his work first, but then I said, I want to make
personal contact with these people, with you, I already know you.
Not so much to say that I don't believe somebody
I don't know, but I think that it does make
a difference in standing up and vouching for it.
Well, because macro psychokinesis is sufficiently
rare and inexplicable that it's on the face
of it, it's unbelievable, and if people don't
take the time and trouble to investigate whether
this could possibly be fraudulent, and in many cases it's simply not the normal kinds
of fraud that you might think of couldn't possibly have occurred.
But the average person doesn't know that.
It would be normal, I think, for a person in a materialistic culture to assume this
is fraudulent, and in fact, the philosopher David Hume put it about 200 years ago or so
that you can assume that anybody who claims to be able to report a miracle is a liar.
Wow.
Wow.
Yeah.
Well, you know, it is again the culture.
I mean, it's like if we go back to ancient Egypt where this kind of thing possibly was
commonplace and there was no concept of, well,
this can't happen, you know, you would have
and, you know, the connection I'm making is that maybe they created macro psychokinesis
through their building of the pyramids or whatever, I mean, so that's the implication
I'm making.
So how does that happen in a culture that doesn't believe, which is, of course, based
a lot on your own belief that you have this ability to connect with matter through to
mind, how does it come up?
Well, like in the case of Katie, she wasn't consciously trying to create her, you know,
the gold leaf that would show up on her body.
She had a kind of brass foil, looked like
gold, that would in effect materialize right
there on her body, and people who look for
our video on the gold leaf lady can actually
see a video clip of that gold leaf materializing right on her skin.
Right, right.
And she had other abilities as well.
Yes.
So, well, you say, well, why does it just happen out of the blue?
Well, it's the same kind of thing that a lot
of our abilities, a lot of the things that
we're not consciously connected with, that some of us have a greater access point to
these things.
You know, talent is one that people will cite.
Why is one person talented at being a pianist and one isn't?
But I use these examples in the book to just
say there is a psyche to matter connection.
And if it's refined, and if it's something
that is again believed in, and there is work
to live in a culture that's open to it, what can it do?
And so we see these things like with Katie.
We're talking about a direct psyche to matter
connection, not one that's mediated by the
muscles.
Right, right.
Although one could argue that how do I, when I
decide to raise my hand, isn't that psychokinesis
also?
Yes, I think it is.
Overmatter?
Right, I think it is, and I talk about that in the book too.
We take it for granted, you know, this every
single thing that we see around us, this studio,
everything is first in the mind.
And it's like there's mind to matter,
because then we go, oh, well, that's nothing.
We have to come up with the tools, we have to come up with, and it's like, well, yeah,
I mean, just lifting your arm, like you said,
is a psyche to matter, you know, process.
But it's really amazing when it's not mediated by the muscles.
Not mediated by a physical mechanism.
And I think that's the distinction between these
things that we look at as being paranormal,
because there is not a physical material mechanism
between the thought and the manifestation.
One of the other examples you cite is the
thoughtography of Ted Sirius, which was investigated
for many years by the psychiatrist, Dr. Jewel
Eisenbud of Denver, who published a book on
the work of Ted Sirius.
I know Stephen Browdy also took a strong interest in this case.
And the archives are now housed in the library
at the University of Maryland, Baltimore.
Which they were almost lost, as you know.
But once again, his mental impressions appear on Polaroid film.
And of course, he was also accused of fraud.
Right.
Right.
And in a way that, of course, just like with
things, the phenomenon like the crop circles,
you know, if one person comes up with a way to
do a mediocre representation or manifestation
through a mechanism, then everything else is wiped out.
And the skeptics that attacked Ted Sirius created
their, oh, well, I can do this, completely
under conditions that, you know, none of
the conditions that were set for Ted Sirius.
No.
If people study the Sirius case, they'll find
that many of the tests were conducted under
such rigorous conditions.
Oh, yeah.
Hugely so.
Hugely so.
So, what is that?
And those are the examples I give that I think
that we're all capable of manipulating matter
in the same way, but in a controlled way, and maybe a more useful way, if we want to,
you know.
Well, Jew Leisenbud, as I mentioned, was a psychiatrist, an Afroidean.
He published a book called Parapsychology and the Unconscious.
And one of the things though that he did, and this is probably particularly relevant
to Westerners, modern Westerners, is that he
didn't want to encourage people to cultivate
these abilities.
He felt that they can come into the service of our own self-destructive impulses.
Well, when they're not disciplined, you know,
I was just having a conversation with somebody
in Toronto that has written a paper on imaginal reality.
And we got into a discussion of the responsibility
of taking the imaginal and presenting it as
reality.
And, you know, we can certainly cite things like schizophrenia.
We can cite any of the psychosis violent crime
that the voices told me to kill these people.
So there is a problem with that.
But the conclusion really is, is that you have to be set, like the ancient Egyptians,
to see this as a sacred endeavor, that it's governed by the rightness of the universe.
Now, what is that?
Who says what is right and what is wrong?
Well, we used to rely on God in our religions,
and that's not as prevalent as it used to
be.
But that's where those kinds of moralities of what's right and wrong, we're certainly
seeing a complete distortion of that in our culture now with fundamentalism.
So I think the horse, you know, can't come before the cart, kind of.
I mean, I think that we do have to develop other things within us before we just start
deciding that we're going to have powers that
we can change the material world and do it
in a bad way.
Now, the third case you cite is my own investigation
of Ted Owens, who called himself the PK Man.
Right.
This is an example of a person who appeared to wield enormous powers.
And in fact, he had a connection with ancient Egypt.
He traveled to Egypt, and he felt that there
were beings, hyperspatial beings inside the
pyramid that he was in touch with, who helped him with some of his manifestations.
And he, in my research with him, which lasted
from 1976 until his death in 1987, he produced
dozens and dozens of demonstrations of what he regarded as psychokinetic abilities.
And what he would do is he would send me written
notifications, I am about to do such and such
a demonstration.
And you will see it because it'll be large
scale, it'll be reported in the media, it'll
be power blackouts, it'll be heat spells in the middle of winter, it'll be cold spells
in the middle of summer, it'll be UFO appearances,
it'll be weird weather, or it'll be controlling
athletic events, causing the favored teams to lose against weaker teams because they
fumbled the ball.
He was roughly two-thirds of the time, these
extraordinary things that were very improbable
actually seemed to happen and would occur after his statement of intention and would
be reported in the newspapers, including on one occasion a UFO appearance.
And he phoned me a few days before it
happened because he could feel something big.
He said, this UFO is going to be seen by hundreds
of people, it's going to be photographed,
and the photograph will be published on the front page of one of your local newspapers.
Well, that happened just a few days after he told me that this was about to occur.
And I don't know when it's ever happened since that a UFO was photographed and the
photograph published on the front page of a newspaper.
In any case, he was like, he regarded himself,
speaking of Egypt, he regarded himself as
being the first person to wield such power since Moses.
Okay.
And he regarded, he felt that these beings
that were helping him were the same ones that
worked with Moses and that he was here to test, like he said, like the canary in the
coal mine, to see how humans, the human population
would respond to somebody with these kinds
of powers.
And typically what would happen, he was something
of a braggart, he'd come into some town and
he'd say, I'm here to save you people from the drought or whatever it was.
And he'd go to the local newspaper.
And oftentimes they would laugh at him and hurl epithets at him and treat him rudely,
like eject him from the newspaper office, which happened on one occasion.
And then he would say, oh, you don't believe
me, I guess I have to teach you a lesson.
And some of those lessons were very unpleasant for the people involved.
So this went on for over a decade, I studied
these circumstances, and even today, years
after his death, there are people who regard
him as a prophet and other people who regard
him as a madman.
I think he probably falls somewhere in between.
But one of the things he surely demonstrated
is that these things are possible.
And I know from anthropologists who work in
shamanistic societies, it's not that uncommon.
It's not uncommon to be a prophet or to be the one that creates the…
To wield such power, for example, in Africa.
Right.
Was it clear that Ted Owens was actually the
one that was creating these phenomena, or
was he just predicting them?
Well, it wasn't 100% clear, because in his
mind he would say, some are predictions, some
I cause through my psychokinetic abilities,
and some of them I telepath to these entities,
these spiritual entities who live in UFOs or who live inside the pyramids.
I just let them know what I'd like them to do, and then they do it.
Right.
Well, there's a lot of factors in there.
One of them, as you know, the schizophrenics
say, as we would classify or diagnose a person
as schizophrenic or psychotic, in primal cultures,
or the medicine men and shamans, they become
because they have connection and ability to go
into the spirit world and go back and forth.
And the early anthropologists thought they were all schizophrenic.
All of the shamans, yeah.
And so you wonder, though, if somebody has this innate ability, like Ted, to be able
to predict or to have the power to do what they
did, and is essentially ignored or ridiculed
or whatever in this culture, that's kind of crazy-making stuff.
I mean, that would be very, very difficult to
deal with from a psychological perspective.
So if you had somebody, say, in the Egyptian
culture that was closer to having more power,
maybe there weren't, maybe it wasn't everybody,
maybe there were just a few people out of
the population, but they were considered great attributes.
See, Ted Owens wanted nothing more than to do good.
That's right.
He was hoping that the US government would recognize his abilities and set up a little
research project so that he could just do
good work and there would be scientists around
who could monitor and observe.
Now, in ancient Egypt, that might have worked out that way.
That's right.
That's right.
Or in ancient Tibet or other ancient cultures.
And again, look at it from the perspective
if this was the norm that we have this power
or whatever you would call it, that it would be more acceptable.
So everyone would be more aware of it and say, oh, yeah, he's just better at it than
the other guy.
And I mean, look at the studies in schizophrenia, using that as an example.
When schizophrenics are treated like everybody
else and they're maybe compensated for in
different ways, they do better.
They do better psychologically and there's
been a lot of research around that, as opposed
to just filling them up with drugs.
Well, that's encouraging because I haven't kept

from the old days is that schizophrenia was practically untreatable.
Oh, yeah.
Yeah.
Yeah.
I mean, I think it was R.D.
Lang that did a lot of work along those lines
with treating them more like, and you know,
that's not necessarily an argument to say,
well, if we treated everybody that had these
powers as normal people, then we would all be
fine, because I think it is still a question.
I mean, I still think it's one of the areas
in my research that still comes up like, hmm,
you know, why is this considered an anomaly and a pathology basically with people?
And I do think some of that is because they're
treated so differently and they're looked

They feel like you're the first person I've told this to kind of thing.
And I think that does have an impact on the

They don't fit in the center of the belt.
Yeah, especially in a materialistic culture

to think you're crazy, whether or not you are.
But when everybody distances themselves from

well it's said there's a very fine line

Oh yeah, oh yeah, yeah.
And you know, these cultures even like even

I mean there were evil spirits, there were evil things.
You know, I don't think they had it down 100% either.
You know, they were pretty wicked themselves

Well you have referred to Rudolf Steiner, we talked about him in an earlier program,

He said that one should take two steps towards

power.
The Yoga Sutras say pretty much the same thing.

Then you can begin to address these powers or cities.
They're quite normal for people, but even then, don't show off.
Yeah, yeah.
And you know, that's a really good point because

We have to deal with those things first before
we're going to be able to harness any of these

It's like if you were abused as a child or if you were beaten or sexually abused and

Well, that's a really good example of that.
I mean, I think in my book, I go through some

Okay, we believe in it now.
What are we going to do with that?
I don't think we have the training or the discipline yet.
No, but I'm hopeful that at some future time,

Well, that's the reason why we write the books

Yes, it has.
